front.title: DetNet data Plane protocol and solution alternatives

abstract.t: This document identifies existing IP and MPLS, and layer-2 encapsulations that run over IP and/or MPLS data plane technologies that could be considered as the base line solution alternatives for deterministic networking data plane definition.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Deterministic networking (DetNet) provides a capability to carry unicast or multicast data streams for real-time applications with extremely low data loss rates and known upper bound maximum latency . The deterministic networking Quality of Service (QoS) is expressed as 1) the minimum and maximum end-to-end latency from sender (talker) to receiver (listener), 2) probability of loss of a packet, 3) probability of loss of a packet in the event of the failure of a relay system or link. Only the worst-case values for the mentioned parameters are concerned.

There are three techniques to achieve the QoS required by deterministic networks:
zero congestion loss, pinned-down paths, packet replications and deletion.
This document identifies existing IP and MPLS, and layer-2 encapsulations that run over IP and/or MPLS data plane technologies that could be considered as the base line solution alternatives for deterministic networking data plane definition. The full scope of the deterministic networking data plane solution is considered including, as appropriate, quality of service (QoS), operations and management (OAM), and time synchronization.

section.title: Requirements for data plane solution alternatives
Zero congestion loss
section.t: Network resources such as link bandwidth, buffers, queues, shapers, and scheduled input/output slots are assigned in each relay system to the use of a specific deterministic networking stream or class of streams. Given a finite amount of buffer space, zero congestion loss necessarily ensures a bounded end-to-end latency. Depending on the resources employed, a minimum latency, and thus bounded jitter, can also be achieved.

section.title: Pinned-down paths
section.t: Point-to-point paths or point-to-multipoint trees through the network from a talker to one or more listeners can be established, and deterministic networking streams assigned to follow a particular path or tree. *[Editor's note]* add a reference to relevant 802.1 spec here.

section.title: Packet replication and deletion
section.t: End systems and/or relay systems can number packets sequentially, replicate them, and later eliminate all but one of the replicants, at multiple points in the network in order to ensure that one (or more) equipment failure events still leave at least one path intact for a deterministic networking stream.

The IEEE 802.1CB specification defines packet sequence numbering, packet replication, and duplicate packet identification and deletion for IEEE 802 family of protocols. The deterministic networking data plane solution alternative at layer-3 MUST provide equivalent functionality.

section.title: Operations and management
section.t: *[Editor's note]* Write that there must be appropriate O&M tools available for the solution alternative. Basically stating that if the solution has no existing standardized management hooks available, it is not really a viable solution.

section.title: Time synchronization
section.t: *[Editor's note]* Write here that it would be desirable if the solution alternative also has associated O&M protocols that are specifically time synchronization specific. One example could be residence time measurement support for MPLS network domain using Generic Associated Channel extensions. Other examples include IEEE 1588 extensions for MPLS.
